Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Manufacturing Mechanically Compliant Silicon Nanostructures for Rechargeable Lithium Ion Batteries

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research project aims at investigating and demonstrating a new concept of manufacturing silicon (Si) anode lithium (Li) ion batteries by utilizing Si nanostructures on elastomeric substrates as anodes to release the stress induced by Li ion diffusion during charge-discharge cycles. Si anodes hold great promise and are being closely investigated for use in Li-ion batteries because they have the highest-known theoretical charge capacity. However, the development of Si-anode Li-ion batteries has lagged behind because of their large physical volume change (4X) during use, specifically during the insertion and extraction of Li ions, which results in pulverization and early capacity fading thus severely limiting their useful life. The objective of this collaborative project is to resolve the stress issue and manufacture Si-anode Li-ion batteries through a fundamental investigation of a novel concept of mechanical-electrochemical coupling of Si nanostructures on elastomeric substrates during insertion and de-insertion of Li ions. Specific studies will focus on (1) a theoretical understanding of releasing diffusion-induced stress using elastomeric substrates; (2) manufacturing of various Si nanostructures on elastomeric substrates as anodes in Li-ion batteries, (3) electrochemical characterization of Li-ion batteries with the nanostructured Si on elastomeric substrates as anode; and (4) development of a cost-effective approach and the realization of manufacturability.

If successful, the results of this collaborative research will facilitate the fundamental understanding in the coupled mechanical-electrochemical properties of Si nanostructures on elastomeric substrates and provide a powerful means to realize theoretically maximum energy density of Si-anode Li-ion batteries. Integrated, interactive and collaborative research and educational programs in two research institutions (University of Delaware and Arizona State University) will be established. The graduate and undergraduate students involved in the proposed research will be trained through a multidisciplinary and multi-university environment. The research achievement will be used to develop and enhance both undergraduate and graduate courses. An innovative outreach activity toward the general public will be established through the collaboration with the Arizona Science Center.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development of high-energy storage devices has been one of the research areas of top-most importance in recent years and rechargeable batteries such as Li-ion batteries are anticipated to be the primary sources of power for modern-day requirements. Si anodes hold great promise and are being closely investigated for use in Li-ion batteries because they have the highest-known theoretical charge capacity. However, the development of Si-anode Li-ion batteries has lagged behind because of their large physical volume change (~4X) during use, specifically during the insertion and extraction of Li ions, which results in pulverization and early capacity fading thus severely limiting their useful life. The objective of this collaborative project is to resolve the stress issue through a fundamental investigation of a novel concept of mechanical-electrochemical coupling of Si nanostructures on elastomeric substrates during insertion and de-insertion of Li ions.

This research project aims at investigating and demonstrating a new concept of manufacturing silicon (Si) anode lithium (Li) ion batteries by utilizing Si nanostructures on elastomeric substrates as anodes to release the stress induced by Li ion diffusion during charge-discharge cycles. Through the four-year investigations, we have successfully demonstrated the proof-of-concept: stress during lithiation can be released by involving Si anodes on soft substrates via buckling. the results of this collaborative research will facilitate the fundamental understanding in the coupled mechanical-electrochemical properties of Si nanostructures on elastomeric substrates and provide a powerful means to realize theoretically maximum energy density of Si-anode Li-ion batteries.

The following highlights the key findings in this research:

(1) Stress during lithiation can be released by involving Si anodes on soft substrates via buckling;

(2) Stress relaxation has achieved long cycle life (more than 500 charging/discharging cycles) and superior capacity retention (84.6%);

(3) Stress relaxation has realized exceptionally high discharging capacity (4,137 mAh/g) (close to the theoretical limit);

(4) The general approach of stress relaxation can be applied to other battery systems when fracture presents.

We have tried to extend the new concept to various Li-ion electrode systems and other energy storage devices including supercapacitors. We have investigated V2O5/SWNT electrodes, MnOx/SWNT electrodes, and α-Fe2O3/SWNT electrodes for Li-ion Batteries. We have also extended to investigate a new supercapacitor system using LaNiO3/NiO Nanostructured Thin Films as the electrodes. The following highlights further findings and new development in this research:

1. We have developed an efficient and facile hydrogen annealing method to enhance rate capability of iron oxide/SWNT hybrid films as Li-ion battery anodes.

2. We have proposed and demonstrated for the first-time a new concept of adhesive conductors employing fragmented carbon nanotube macro-films (FCNTs).

3. We have build all solid state supercapacitors with reduced graphene oxides and observed an interesting electrochemical phenomenon, which attracted our attention to understand the fundamentals.

4. We have continued our research to apply the stress release principles to build Stretchable Wire-shaped Supercapacitors.

5. We, for the first time, successfully implemented a stretchable pseudocapacitor with buckled MnO2/CNT hybrid electrodes to make a fully stretchable, rechargeable energy storage device, demonstrating the important proof-of-concept. The extremely small relaxation time constants explain fundamentally that repeated stretching and releasing at the applied strain rates will not affect the stable performance of the stretchable pseudocapacitors.
